changes.name: Third or Progressive palatalization
changes.description: The velar obstruents *k, *g, *x changed to *tˊ, *dˊ, *ś if they were immediately preceded by *i, *ī, or *j, or by sequences consisting of *i and a nasal *n

changes.name: Umlaut
changes.description: Back vowels were fronted after the palatal consonants *j, *tˊ,*dˊ, and *ś: *u > *i, *ū > *ī, *a > *e, *ā > *ē

changes.name: Monophthongization
changes.description: Tautosyllabic sequences of vowel and *w or *j were monophthongized: *aw, *āw, *ew, *ēw > *ọ̄; *aj, *āj > *ē; *ej, *ēj > *ẹ̄ > *ī

changes.name: Depalatalization
changes.description: *ē was backened to *ā after the palatal consonants *j, *č, *dž, *š, *tˊ, *dˊ, *ś

changes.name: w-prothesis before *u-, *ū-
changes.description: Word-initial *u-, *ū- received a prothetic glide *w: *u-, *ū- > *wu-, *wū-

changes.name: The change of *ẹ̄ to *ī
changes.description: *ẹ̄, which had been introduced as a result of the monophthongization of *ej, changed to *ī

changes.name: Second regressive palatlization
changes.description: The velar obstruents *k, *g, *x changed to *tˊ, *dˊ, *ś if they were immediately by a front vowel resulting from monophthongization or by a sequence consisting of *w and a front vowel resulting from monophthongization

changes.name: l-epenthesis
changes.description: A lateral *l was inserted between the labial consonants *p, *b, *m, *w and an immediately following *j

changes.name: The change of *ś to *s'
changes.description: Palatal *ś resulting from one of the two Common Slavic palatalizations (§§ 1, 7) change to palatalized *sʼ

changes.name: Liquid metathesis
changes.description: Acute word-initial sequences of *ar-, *al- followed by a consonant other than *j change to *rā˙-, *lā˙-, and non-acute to *ra-, *la-

changes.name: Dybo's law
changes.description: The accented shifted from a non-acute syllable onto the immediatly following syllable

changes.name: Meillet's metatony
changes.description: Acute tone was dropped on unaccented syllables

changes.name: Assibilation of *t' to *c' and of *d' to *dz'
changes.description: *tˊ and dʼ resulting from one of two Common Slavic palatalizations (§§ 1, 7) assibilated to *cʼ and *dzʼ

changes.name: The change of *kt to *k't' before front vowels and *j
changes.description: *kt change to kˊtˊ before immediately preceding front vowels (*e, *ē, *i, *ī) and *j

changes.name: Shortening of tautosyllabic sequences *ān, *ēn to *an, *en
changes.description: The long vowels *ā, *ē were shortened before a tautosyllabic nasal *n: *ān, *ēn > *an, *en

changes.name: The change of *kt to *t and of *k't' to *t'
changes.description: The sequences *kt and *k't' were simplified to *t and *t', respectively

changes.name: Delabialization *ū > *ȳ
changes.description: *ū was delabialized to *ȳ

changes.name: Jotation
changes.description: Sequences of a dental consonant and *j, cf. *tj, *dj, *sj, *zj, *rj, *lj, *nj, were "jotated" to *tˊj, *dˊj, *šj, *žj, *rʼj, *lˊj, *ńj; *s or *z immediately preceding a corresponding sequcne, was affected by the change as well: *stj, *zdj, *slj > *štˊj, *ždˊj, *šlˊj etc.

changes.name: The change of *CelC to *CalC and of *CilC to *CulC
changes.description: Before a tautosyllabic lateral *l, the front vowels *e and *i changed to *a and *u, respectively

changes.name: The change of *tl, *dl to *l
changes.description: The sequences *tl and *dl were simplified to *l

changes.name: The change of *t' to *č and of *d' to *dž
changes.description: *tˊ, *dˊ resulting from the change *kˊtˊ > tˊ (§ 16) and from Jotation (§ 18) developed further to *č and dž, respectively

changes.name: The rise of pleophony
changes.description: Tautosyllabic word-internal sequences *-al-, *-ar-, *-er-, *-el- changed to *-ala-, *-ara-, *-ere-, *-ele-; if the original seqence was accented, which was the case when it bore the acute tone or when it had received the accent as a result of Dybo's law (§ 11), the pleonastic sequence received an accent on the second syllable; NB: before *j, *-al-, *-ar-, *-er-, *-el- were heterosyllabic

changes.name: The change of *a to *o
changes.description: Short *a changed to *o

changes.name: j-prothesis
changes.description: The word initial front vowels *e, *ē, *i, *ī, and *ā received a prothetic *j: *e-, *ē-, *i-, *ī-, *ā- > *je-, *jē-, *ji-, *jī-, *jā-

changes.name: The rise of nasal vowels
changes.description: Tautosyllabic sequences *en, *eń, *em, *in, *iń, *im changed to *ę̄ and tautosyllabic sequences *on, *oń, *om, *un, *uń, *um to *ǭ; NB: the corresponding sequences were heterosyllabic before *j and *lj

changes.name: The change of *ē > *ě̄
changes.description: PSl. *ē and *ē that resulted from monophthongization of aj, āj (§ 3) was raised to *ẹ̄, which is traditionally referred to as „Jat“ (ě), i.e., by the name that is used to write the corresponding sound in Old Church Slavonic

changes.name: The change of *i to *ь and of *u to *ъ
changes.description: Short *i and *u changed to *ь and *ъ, respectively; the pronunciation of the latter sounds was most probably located between that of *i and *u and of schwa.

changes.name: Shortening of word-final long vowels
changes.description: Word-final long vowels were shortened in polysyllabic words; an acute tone was erased in the course of this shortening

changes.name: Loss of post-consonantal *j and Kortlandt's compensatory lengthening
changes.description: Postconsonantal *j was lost; as a result of this loss, an immediately following vowel was lengthened

changes.name: Jer-epenthesis
changes.description: Word-final consonant-sonorant-jer sequences were dissolved by inserting a jer between the consonant and the sonorang; the quality of the inserted jer depended on its environment: after velar consonants *ъ was inserted, after dental and labial consonants *ь, and if the sonorant was *w, the inserted vowel was *ъ

changes.name: The rise of secondary palatalization before front vowels
changes.description: Non-soft consonants became secondarily palatalized before front vowels

changes.name: Denasalization of *ę, *ę̄ to *a, *ā and of *ǫ, *ǭ to *ọ, *ọ̄
changes.description: Nasal vowels were denasalized: *ę, *ę̄ > *a, *ā and *ǫ, *ǭ > *ọ, *ọ̄

changes.name: The change of word-initial *jь- to *i-
changes.description: Word-initial *jь- change to *i-; this includes sequences of *jь- that were introduced by j-prothesis (§ 24)

changes.name: The rise of a difference between strong and weak jers
changes.description: Jers (*ъ, *ь) were strong when they occurred in tautosyllabic sequences before or after liquids (*r, *l), after nasals (*m, *n), and after *w, and in subsequent syllables containing jers in every even syllable counted from right to left; in other positions, jers counted as weak

changes.name: Ivšić's first law
changes.description: The accent shifted one syllable to the left from non-acute long vowels

changes.name: Ivšić's second law
changes.description: The accent shifted one syllable to the left from weak jers

changes.name: The loss of the acute tone
changes.description: The acute tone was lost

changes.name: The change of *ọ, *ọ̄ to *u, *ū
changes.description: *ọ̄, *ọ resulting from monophthongization (§ 3) and denasalization (§ 33) change to *ū, *u

changes.name: The change of *dž to *ž
changes.description: *dž resulting from Jotation of *t and from the pre-Proto-Slavic First regressive Palatalization changed to *ž

changes.name: The change of *īj to *ь2j and of *ūj to *ъ2j
changes.description: Long *ī and *ū followed by a glide *j changed to strong jers: *īj > *ь2j and *ūj > *ъ2j, respectively

changes.name: The loss of word-initial *j- before *ī and *ū
changes.description: Word-initial *j- was lost before *ī and *ū

changes.name: The change of *ji, *jī to *i and of *wu, *wū to *u
changes.description: The glides *j and *w were lost before tautosyllabic high vowels: *ji, *jī > *i and *wu, *wū > *u, respectively

changes.name: The shift of stress from post-hiatal *i, *ī and *u, *ū to an immediately preceding syllable
changes.description: The accent shifted by one syllable to the left from *i, *ī, *u, *ū that were preceded by a hiatus as a result of change of *ji, *jī to *i and of *wu, *wū to *u; in the course of this change *i, *ī and *u, *ū change to *j and *w, respectively

changes.name: The change of stressed *o to *ô
changes.description: Stressed *o was raised to *ô

changes.name: The change of word-inital *je- to *o-
changes.description: Word-initial *je- change to *o- if it was immediately followed by a soft consonantsand if certain other conditions that have been proven difficult to determine were fulfilled

changes.name: The change of *dz to *z'
changes.description: *dz resulting from the Third and the Second palatalizations changed to palatalized *z'

changes.name: The rise of secondary alatalization of *r in tautosyllabic position before *ь immediately followed by velars, labials, or palatalized dentals
changes.description: *r became palatalized in the position after *ь before a velar, labial, or palatalized dental consonant

changes.name: The loss of weak jers
changes.description: *ъ and *ь were lost in weak position

changes.name: Regressive assimilation before palatal consonants
changes.description: As a result of the loss of weak years consonant clusters with a palatal as their final member arose; in these clusters, consonants assimilated to the palatal consonant

changes.name: Simplification of consonant clusters
changes.description: Certain consonant clusters resulting from the loss of weak jers were simplified

changes.name: The change of palatal *l', *n' to palatalized *l', *n'
changes.description: Palatal nasals and laterals (*l', *n') which had been introduced as a result of Jotation (§ 18) changed to their palatalized counterparts (*l', *n')

changes.name: The change of *ь to *e and of *ъ to *o
changes.description: *ъ and *ь which had been retained because they occurred in strong position (§ 34)

changes.name: The rise of stress in unaccentuated accentual units
changes.description: Unaccented accentual units received a stress on their initial syllable

changes.name: w-prothesis before *ô
changes.description: Word initial *ô received a prothetic *w

changes.name: The change of *w to *v
changes.description: Bilabial *w changed to labiodental *v

changes.name: Regressive voice assimilation in consonant sequences and word-final devoicing
changes.description: In consonant clusters which had arisen as a result of the loss of weak jers, voiced consonants that took part in the voicing correlation assimilated to a following unvoiced consonant and vice versa; word-final voiced consonants were devoiced

changes.name: Hardening of *š to *ṡ͘, and of *ž to *ż
changes.description: Soft *š and *ž changed to hard *ṡ͘ and *ż

changes.name: Depalatalization of word-final *m' to *m
changes.description: Palatalized *m' in word-final position was depalatalized to *m

changes.name: The change of *e to *o before hard consonants
changes.description: PSl. *e and *e resulting from the change *ь > *e (§ 52) change to *o if they were immediately followed by a hard consonant

changes.name: Hardening of *c' to *c
changes.description: Soft *c' changed to hard *c

changes.name: Regressive secondary palatalization assimilation
changes.description: In consonant clusters which had arisen as a result of the loss of weak jers, most palatalized consonants assimilated to a following unpalatalized consonant and vice versa

changes.name: The change of *i, *ī to *y, *ȳ after hard consonants
changes.description: After hard consonants, high front vowels were backened: *i, *ī > *y, *ȳ

changes.name: The change of *y, *ȳ to *i, *ī after velar consonants
changes.description: After the velar consonants *k, *g, and *x, *y, *ȳ were fronted to *i, *ī

changes.name: Secondary palatalization of *k, *g, *x by following front vowels
changes.description: The velar consonants *k, *g, and *x became palatalized before immediately following front vowels

changes.name: Shortening of long vowels
changes.description: Long vowels were shortened

changes.name: The change of *ě to *i before palatalized dentals followed by a stressed front vowel or a
changes.description: Jat (ě) changed to *i if it was followed by a sequence consisting of a paltalized dental consonant and a stressed front vowel or *a

changes.name: Reduction of unstressed vowels
changes.description: Apart from *u, unvoiced vowels were reduced; the quality of the resulting reduced vowel depended on the on its position in relation to the stressed syllable and on whether a preceding consonant was palatalized

changes.name: Loss of non-palatalized *l in word-final position
changes.description: Postconsonental non-palatalized *l was lost in word-final position

changes.name: The change of *šč to *šš and of *ždž to *žž
changes.description: The second member of the sequences *šč and *ždž  were deaffricated: *šč > *šš, *ždž > *žž

changes.name: The change of *ě to *e
changes.description: Jat (*ě) merged with *e

changes.name: The change of *ô to *o
changes.description: Closed *ô merged with *o

relations.description: Feeding: Palatal consonants resulting from the Third Palatalization (§ 1) triggered umlaut (§ 2), e.g. PSl. *su̠l˙nika > *su̠l˙nitˊa > *su̠l˙nitˊe > Ru. so̠ncə. Hence the Third Palatalization must be older than umlaut.
Counterfeeding: High front vowels resulting from umlaut (§ 2) did not trigger the Third Palatalization (§ 1), e.g. PSl. *juga > *jiga > Ru. i̠gə and not *juga > *jiga > *jidˊa etc.
Feeding: The Third Palatalization (§ 1) created inputs for the change of *ś to *sʼ (§ 9), cf. PSl. *wi̠xa > *wi̠śa > *wi̠sʼe > Ru fʼsʼo̠.

Feeding: The Third Palatalization (§ 1) created inputs for the Assibilation of *t' and *d' to *c' and  *dz', respectively, cf. PSl. *awi̠kā˙ > *awi̠tˊā˙ > *awicʼā̠˙ > Ru. ʌfca̠; PSl *kuningu > *kunińdˊu > *kunińdzʼi > Ru. knʼa̠sʼ.

Loanword: The loanwords Fi. arnitsa 'thick linen' (cf. ORu or(ь)nica), Fi. katitsa 'fishing weir' (cf. gen. sg. ursl. *kati̠kā), and Estn. narits 'European mink' (cf. PSl. *na̠rī˙kā˙) reflect a stage posterior to the Third Palatalization (§ 1) but prior to the change of PSl *a to *o (§ 23)
Feeding: Umlaut (§ 2) of *aj to *ej created inputs for the monophthongization of *ej to *ī (§ 3), cf. PSl *ja̠jxu > *je̠jxu > *jī̠xu > Ru i̠x.
Bleeding: Umlaut (§ 2) of *aj to *ej withdrew inputs from the monophthongization of *aj to *ē (§ 3), cf. PSl *ja̠jxu > *je̠jxu > *jī̠xu > Ru i̠x.
Feeding: Umlaut (§ 2) created inputs for the depalatalization of *ē to *ā (§ 4), cf. PSl. *brā̠˙tijā˙ > *brā̠˙tijē˙ > *brā̠˙tijā˙ > Ru. bra̠tʼjɪ.

Counterbleeding: Assuming that Umlaut (§ 2) occurred only after palatal consonants, the change of *ś to *sʼ (§ 9) would have withdrawn imputs from Umlaut (§ 2), had the former occurred before the latter. Hence PSl. *wi̠xa > *wi̠śa > *wi̠śe > *wi̠sʼe > Ru. fʼsʼo̠ would show that Umlaut (§ 2) occurred before the change of *ś to *sʼ (§ 9).
Bleeding: Umlaut (§ 2) of *ū to *ī withdrew inputs from the change of *ū to *ȳ (§ 17), cf.  PSl. *sjū̠˙jā˙ > *sjī̠˙jē˙ > Ru. ṡe̠jə (or did umlaut affect *ȳ?).

Counterfeeding: Had j-Prothesis (§ 24) occurred before Umlaut (§ 2), the former change would have created inputs for the latter. That it had not is shown by the lack of umlaut in Ru. я̠блоко  'apple'. Otherwise the initial vocalism in Ru. я̠блоко < PSl. *ā̠˙bluka could be explained only if Depalatalization (§ 4) is dated after j-prothesis which seems to be contradicted by PSl. *ē̠˙stēj > Ru. je̠sʼtʼ.
Feeding: The monophthongization of *ej to *ẹ̄ (§ 3) created inputs for the change of *ẹ̄ to *ī (§ 6), cf. PSl. *zejmā̠˙ > *zẹ̄mā̠˙ > *zīmā̠˙ > Ru. zʼima̠.

Feeding: The monophthongization (§ 3) created inputs for the Second Palatalization (§ 7), cf. PSl. *kajnā̠˙ > *kēnā̠˙ > *tˊēnā̠˙ > Ru. cəna̠; PSl. *kwajtu > *kwētu > *tˊwētu > Ru. cvʼe̠t; PSl. *gwa̠jzdā˙ > *gwē̠zdā˙ > *dˊwē̠zdā˙ > Ru. zʼvʼɪzda̠.

Bleeding: The monophthongization of *aw, *āw, *ew, *ēw to *ọ̄ (§ 3) withdrew inputs from l-epenthesis (§ 8), cf. PSl. *čja̠w˙jete > *čjọ̠̄˙jete > Ru. ču̠jɪtʼɪ and not PSl. *čja̠w˙jete > *čje̠w˙jete > **čje̠w˙ljete > **čjọ̠̄˙ljete > Ru. **ču̠ljʼɪtʼɪ
Feeding: The monophthongization of *aj, *āj to *ē (§ 3) created inputs for *ē to *ě̄ (§ 26), cf. PSl, *sē̠˙weru > *sě̠̄˙weru > Ru. sʼe̠vʼɪr; PSl. *stajnā̠˙ > *stēnā̠˙ > *stě̄nā̠˙ > Ru. sʼtʼɪna̠.
Loanword: The toponym Lat. Ma̠ximus > rom.*Ma̠jsẹmu > Sl. *Ma̠jsьmъ > Čak. Ma̠jsan was borrowed after the Monophthongization (§ 3) but before the change of *i to *ь (§ 27).
Feeding: The monophthongization of *aj, *āj to *ě̄ (§ 28) created inputs for the shortening of word-final long vowels (§ 28), cf. PSl. *u wu̠nāj > *wu wuně̠̄ > *wъ wъně̠ > Ru. vʌvnʼe̠.

Feeding: The monophthongation of *aj, *āj to *ē (§ 3) created inputs for the rize of secondary palatalization before front vowels (§ 31), cf. PSl. *stajnā̠˙ > *stě̄na̠ > *stʼě̄na̠ > Ru. sʼtʼɪna̠; PSl. *ta̠jxu > *tě̄xъ̠ > *tʼě̄xъ̠ > Ru. tʼe̠x.
Loanword: The loanword Latv. ļùoti (cf. PSl *lja̠wtu) reflects a stage posterior to Monophthongization (§ 3) but prior to Ivšić's Law (§ 36).
Feeding: The monophthongization of *aw, *āw, *ew, *ēw to *ọ̄ (§ 3) created inputs for the change of *ọ̄ to *ū (§ 8) PSl. *ba̠w˙rjā˙ > *ba̠w˙rjē˙ > *bọ̠̄˙rjē˙ > Ru. bu̠rʼɪ.

Counterfeeding: Had the Second Palatalization (§ 7) occurred before the Depalatalization (§ 4), the former change would have created inputs for the latter, cf. PSl. *kajnā̠˙ > *kēnā̠˙ > *tˊēnā̠˙ > Ru. cəna̠ and not PSl. *kajnā̠˙ > *kēnā̠˙ > *tˊēnā̠˙ > **tˊānā̠˙ > Ru. **cʌna̠.
Counterbleeding: Had the change *ś > *sʼ (§ 9) occurred before the Depalatalization (§ 4), the former change would have withdrawn inputs from the latter.

Bleeding: The Depalatalization (§ 4) withdrew inputs from the shortening of word-final *ēn to *en, cf. PSl. *me̠ljān > *me̠ljēn > *meljā̠n > *melja̠n > Ru mʼɪlʼu̠; PSl *zejmān > *zejmēn > *zejmān > *zīman > Ru. zʼi̠mu.

Counterfeeding: Had the j-Prothesis occurred before the Depalatalization (§ 4), the former change would have created inputs for the latter, cf. PSl. *ē̠˙stēj > Ru. je̠sʼtʼ, and not *ē̠˙stēj > **jē̠˙stēj > **jā̠˙stēj > Ru. **ja̠sʼtʼ.
Feeding: The Depalatalization (§ 4) created inputs for the shortening of word-final long vowels (§ 28), cf. PSl. *wa̠ljā˙ > *wa̠ljē˙ > *wa̠ljā˙ > *wolˊjā̠ > *wolˊja̠ > Ru. vo̠lʼɪ.

Counterbleeding: Had the shortening of long vowels (§ 65) occurred before the Depalatalization (§ 4), the former change would have withdrawn inputs from the latter, cf. PSl. *džē̠˙li > *džā̠˙li > Ru. ża̠lʼ, and not PSl. *džē̠˙li > **dže̠˙li > Ru. **że̠lʼ.

Loanword: The Croatian toponym O̠.ciń (< Sl *Ulkī̠˙nju < Rom. *Ọlkẹ̠̄nʼu < Lat. Olci̠nium) was borrowed posterior to the operation of w-prothesis (§ 5) but prior to the Second Palatalization (§ 7).

Counterbleeding: It is phonetically less plausible that w developed before *ȳ. Had the change of *ū to *ȳ (§ 17) occurred before w-Prothesis (§ 5), the former change would have withdrawn inputs from the latter (§ 5).

Feeding: It is phonetically more plausible that the prothetic consonant resulting from w-Prothesis (§ 5) was homorganic with the preceding vowel and hence, occurred before the change of *w to *v (§ 55).

Counterfeeding: Had the change of *ē to *ě̄ (§ 26) occurred before the change of *ẹ̄ to *ī (§ 6), the former change would have created intputs for the latter since it is likely that *ě̄ presented a closed e-vowel.
Feeding: The Second Palatalization (§ 7) of PSl. *x to *ś created inputs for the change of *ś to sʼ (§ 9).

Feeding: The Second Palatalization (§ 7) created inputs for the assibilation of *t' to *c' and of *d' to *dz', cf. PSl. *kajnā̠˙ > tˊēnā̠˙ > *cʼēnā̠˙ > Ru. cəna̠; PSl. *kwajtu > *tˊwētu > *cʼwētu > Ru. cvʼe̠t; PSl *gwa̠jzdā˙ > *dˊwē̠zdā˙ > *dzʼwēzdā̠˙ > Ru. zʼvʼɪzda̠

Loanword: The toponym Lat. *Quirī̠nus > Rom. *Kẹrī̠nu > Sl. *Kirī̠nu > Čak. Ka̠rin was borrowed into Croation only after the operation of the Second Palatalization(§ 7), but before Ivšić's  first law (§ 35).
Feeding: l-Epenthesis (§ 8) created inputs for the jotation of *lj to *lˊ (§ 18), cf. PSl. *bjawstē̠j > *bljọ̄stī̠ > *blˊjọ̄stī̠ > Ru. blʼustʼi̠.

Counterbleeding: Had the loss of postconsonantal *j (§ 29) occurred before l-Epenthesis (§ 8), the former change would have withdrawn inputs from the latter, cf. PSl. *zemjā̠˙ > *zemlˊja̠ > *zemlˊa̠ > Ru. zʼɪmlʼa̠ and not *zemjā̠˙ > **zemā̠˙ etc.

Feeding: l-Epenthesis (§ 8) created inputs for jer-Epenthesis (§ 30), cf. PSl. *zemju̠ > *zemlji̠ > *zemlˊь̠ > *zemьlˊь̠ > Ru. zʼɪmʼe̠lʼ; PSl. *kā̠˙pju > *kā̠˙plji > *kā̠˙plˊь > *kā̠˙pьlˊь Ru. ka̠pʼɪlʼ.
Loanword: The loanword Fi. luota (cf. PSl. *bja̠w˙da) reflects a stage posterior to l-Epenthesis (§ 8), but prior to the change of *ọ̄ to *ū (§ 38).

Counterfeeding: Had the loss of weak jers (§ 48) occurred before the l-Epenthesis, the former change would have created inputs for the latter, cf. PSl. *karbi̠jā˙ > *korobь1ja̠ > *korobja̠ > Ru. kərʌbja̠.

Counterfeeding: Unstressed word-initial liquid diphthongs which had the feature "acute" developed in the same way as stressed word-initial liquid diphthongs, i.e.  cf. Ukr. ратa̠й. Had Meillet's metatony (§ 12) eliminated the acute in unstressed syllables before liquid metathesis (§ 10), the former change would have created input for the latter, cf. cf. *a̠R˙C- > *rā̠˙C- and not *a̠R˙C- > *a̠RC- > *ra̠C-.

Counterbleeding: Unstressed word-initial liquid diphthongs which have the feature "acute" develop in the same way as stressed word-initial liquid diphthongs, i.e.  cf. Ukr. ратa̠й. Had Meillet's metatony (§ 12) eliminated the acute in unstressed syllables before liquid metathesis (§ 10), the former change would have withdrawn inputs from the latter, cf. *a̠R˙C- > *rā̠˙C-, not *a̠R˙C- > *a̠RC- > *ra̠C-.
Bleeding: The liquid metathesis (§ 10) withdrew inputs from the change of *CelC to *CalC and of *CilC to *CulC, cf. PSl. *elbedā̠˙ > *lebedā̠˙ > Ru lʼɪbʼɪda̠ and not *elbedā̠˙ > **albedā̠˙ etc.

Feeding: The loss of word-initial *j- before *ī and *ū (§ 41) created inputs for the shift of stress from post-hiatal *i, *ī and *u, *ū to an immediately preceding syllable (§ 43), cf. PSl. *zā ja̠w˙trā > *zā ū̠tra > *zā̠ wtra > Ru. za̠vtrə.
Feeding: The change of *jī to *i and of *wū to *u (§ 42) created inputs for the shift of stress from post-hiatal *i, *ī and *u, *ū to an immediately preceding syllable (§ 43).

Feeding: The change of *jī, *ji to *i and of *wū, *wu to *u (§ 42) created inputs for the change of *i, *ī to *y, *ȳ after hard consonants (§ 62), cf. PSl. *uz e̠jskā˙tēj > *wъz jīskā̠˙tī > *wъ1z jīskā̠tʼi > *wъ1z īskā̠tʼi > *vzīskā̠tʼ > *vzȳskā̠tʼ > russ. vzyska̠tʼ.
Feeding: The shift of stress from post-hiatal *i, *ī and *u, *ū to an immediately preceding syllable (§ 43) created inputs for the change of stressed *o to *ô (§ 44).
Counterfeeding: Had the change of *o to ô (§ 44) occurred prior to the the change of *ъ to *o (§ 52), the former change would have created inputs for the latter.
Counterfeeding: Had the rise of stress in unaccentuated accentual units (§ 53) occurred before the change of *o to *ô (§ 44), the former change would have created inputs for the latter.
Feeding: The change of *o to *ô (§ 44) created inputs for the w-prothesis before word-initial *ô (§ 54).
Counterfeeding: Had the change of *e to *o before hard consonants (§ 59) occurred prior to the change of *o to *ô (§ 44), the former change would have created inputs for the latter.
Counterbleeding: Had the change of *ž to *ż (§ 57) occurred prior to the change of *je- to *o- (§ 45), the former change would have created inputs for the latter, cf. OESl. ožь 'hedghog'.

Bleeding: The rise of secondary alatalization of *r in tautosyllabic position before *ь immediately followed by velars, labials, or palatalized dentals (§ 47) withdrew inputs from the change of *e to *o before hard consonants (§ 59), cf. *wi̠rxu > *wʼь̠2rxъ1 > *wʼь̠2rʼxъ1 > Ru. vʼe̠rx.
Feeding: The loss of weak jers (§ 48) created inputs for the regressive assimilation before palatal consonants (§ 49).
Feeding: The loss of weak jers (§ 48) created inputs for the simplification of consonant clusters (§ 50).

Feeding: The loss of weak jers (§ 48) created inputs for the rise of stress in unaccentuated accentual units (§ 53), cf. *duskān >*dъ1sku > *dsku reintroduction of *ъ in do dissolve the consonant cluster dъ1sku > Ru. do̠sku and not Ru. *duskān > **dъ̠1sku > **dsku̠ > reintroduction of *ъ in do dissolve the consonant cluster > **dъ1sku̠ > russ. **dəsku̠.
Feeding: The loss of weak jers (§ 48) created inputs for the regressive voice assimilation in consonant sequences and word-final devoicing (§ 56).
Feeding: The loss of weak jers (§ 48) created inputs for the depalatalization of word-final *m' to *m (§ 58).
Feeding: The loss of weak jers (§ 48) created inputs for the regressive secondary palatalization assimilation (§ 61).

Feeding: The loss of weak jers (§ 48) created inputs for the change of *i, *ī to *y, *ȳ after hard consonants (§ 62), cf. PSl. *uz e̠jskā˙tēj > *wъz jīskā̠˙tī > *wъ1z jīskā̠tʼi > *wъ1z īskā̠tʼi > *vzīskā̠tʼ > *vzȳskā̠tʼ > Ru. vzyska̠tʼ.
Feeding: The loss of weak yers (§ 48) created inputs for vowel reduction (§ 67).
Feeding: The loss of weak jers (§  48) created inputs for the loss of non-palatalized *l in word-final position (§ 48).

Counterbleeding: Had the change of palatal *l', *n' to palatalized *l', *n' (§ 51) occurred prior to the regressive assimilation before palatal consonants (§ 49), the former change would have withdrawn inputs from the latter.

Plausibility: It is phonetically more plausible to assume that *š, *ž resulting from assimilation before palatal  consonants (§ 49) were originally soft which suggests that the hardening of *š to *ṡ͘, and of *ž to *ż (§ 57) occurred at later stage, cf. *su̠ljān > *sъ1lˊu̠ > *slˊu̠ > *šlˊu̠ > *šlʼu̠ > Ru. ṡlʼu̠.

Feeding: The regressive assimilation before palatal consonants (§ 49) created inputs for the change of *šč to *šš and of *ždž to *žž  (§ 69), cf. PSl. *sučenstija > *sъ1čāstʼь1je > *sčāstʼje > *šča̠stʼji > Ru. šša̠stʼjɪ.

Feeding: The simplification of consonant clusters (§ 50) created inputs for the hardening of *š to *ṡ͘, and of *ž to *ż (§ 57), cf. PSl. *pa̠rzdinjuju > *porô̠ždžńь2j > *porô̠žńь2j > *porô̠žnʼej > *porô̠żnʼej > Ru. pʌro̠żnʼɪj where the sequence *ždžń had to be simplified to žń before *ž could change to *ż.
Counterfeeding: Had the change of *šč to *šš and of *ždž to *žž (§ 69) occurred before the simplification of consonant clusters (§ 50), the former change would have withdrawn inputs for the latter.
Feeding: The change of ь to e (§ 52) created inputs for the change of *e to *o before hard consonants (§ 59).
Feeding: The rise of stress in unaccentuated accentual units (§ 53) created inputs for vowel reduction (§ 67).
Feeding: The w-prothesis before *ô (§ 54) created inputs for the change of *w to *v (§ 55).
Counterbleeding: Had the change of *ô to *o (§ 71) occurred prior to the w-prothesis (§ 54), the former change would have withdrawn inputs from the latter.
Feeding: The change of *š to *ṡ and of *ž to *ż (§ 57) created inputs for the change of *e to *o before hard consonants (§ 59), cf. PSl. *malde̠džju > *molodʼe̠ṡ > *molodʼo̠ṡ > Ru. məlʌdʼo̠ṡ.
Feeding: The change of *š to *ṡ and of *ž to *ż (§ 57) created inputs for the change of *i, *ī to *y, *ȳ after hard consonants (§ 62).
Feeding: The depalatalization of word-final *m' to *m (§ 58) created inputs for the change of *e to *o before hard consonants (§ 59), cf. PSl. *dinimi > *dʼnʼe̠mʼ > *dʼnʼe̠m > Ru. dʼnʼo̠m.

Counterfeeding: Had the hardening of *c' to *c (§ 69) occurred prior to the change of *e to *o before hard consonants (§ 59), the former change would have created inputs for the latter, cf. PSl. *awi̠ku > *ovʼe̠cʼ > *ovʼe̠c > Ru. ʌvʼe̠c suggests where *cʼ was still soft when the change of *e to *o before hard consonants (§ 59).

Counterfeeding: Had the regressive secondary palatalization assimilation (§ 61) occrred prior to the change of *e to *o before hard consonants, the former change would have created inputs for the latter, cf.  PSl. *že̠niskuju > *že̠nʼskoj > *že̠nskoj > Ru. že̠nskəj and not PSl. *že̠niskuju > *že̠nʼskoj > *že̠nskoj > **žo̠nskoj > Ru.** žo̠nskəj.
Counterfeeding: Had the change of *ě to *e (§ 70) occurred prior to the change of *e to *o before hard consonants (§ 59), the former change would have created inputs for the latter.
Feeding: The change of *cʼ to *c (§ 60) created inputs for the regressive secondary palatalization assimilation (§ 61), cf. PSl. *awi̠kā˙ > *ofʼcʼa̠ > *ofʼca̠ > *ofca̠ > Ru. ʌfca̠.
Feeding: The change of *cʼ to *c (§ 60) created inputs for the change of *i, *ī to *y, *ȳ (§ 62).
Plausibility: The reversed order (i.e., § 63 before § 62) would require to limit the change of *i to *y after hard consonants (§ 62) to all hard consonants but velars which seems implausible.
Feeding: The change of *y, *ȳ to *i, *ī after velar consonants (§ 63) created inputs for the palatalization of *k, *g, *x before front vowels (§ 64).

Loanword: The loanwords Finn. kiisseli and Latv. ķĩselis `both: kind of jelly' (cf. Ru. kisel' `kind of jelly') reflect a stage before the shortening of long vowels (§ 65), but after the change of *y to *i after velar consonants (§ 63).
Bleeding: The change of *ě to *i before palatalized dentals followed by a stressed front vowel or *a withdrew inputs from the change of *ě to *e (§ 70).
